content: How can one define the homotopy level of a Kan complex? Note that this notion is pretty unrelated to the notion of dimension of a Kan complex: take any groupoid with a non-identity morphism, then the nerve of that groupoid will be infinite-dimensional, while its homotopy level should be 1.

@Leopold Schlicht A Kan complex XXX "has homotopy level ≤n\leq n≤n”, or "is an nnn-type”, if for every k>n+1k > n+1k>n+1, every map of simplicial sets ∂Δk→X\partial\Delta^{k} \to X∂Δk→X extends to a map Δk→X\Delta^{k} \to XΔk→X, or equivalently, if for every m>nm > nm>n, and every base point x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, the homotopy group πm(X,x)\pi_m(X,x)πm​(X,x) is trivial.
The second definition needs some tweaking for n<0n < 0n<0.
And of course, a Kan complex "has homotopy level nnn” if it has homotopy level ≤n\leq n≤n but not homotopy level ≤n−1\leq n-1≤n−1.

Alexander Campbell said:

The second definition needs some tweaking for n<0n < 0n<0.

For example π0\pi_0π0​ is a set, while π−1\pi_{-1}π−1​ is a mere truth value.

Alexander Campbell said:

And of course, a Kan complex "has homotopy level nnn” if it has homotopy level ≤n\leq n≤n but not homotopy level ≤n−1\leq n-1≤n−1.

I don't think that's a very useful definition. I'm more inclined to use "homotopy level nnn" to mean just "is an nnn-type".

John Baez said:

Alexander Campbell said:

The second definition needs some tweaking for n<0n < 0n<0.

For example π0\pi_0π0​ is a set, while π−1\pi_{-1}π−1​ is a mere truth value.

But with that modification it does work, right? Where "trivial" means "isomorphic to the terminal object" of whatever category it lies in?
@Mike Shulman I agree it's not a useful definition, but I guess to my ear one can be only on one "level" and not on another.

Mike Shulman said:

John Baez said:

Alexander Campbell said:

The second definition needs some tweaking for n<0n < 0n<0.

For example π0\pi_0π0​ is a set, while π−1\pi_{-1}π−1​ is a mere truth value.

But with that modification it does work, right? Where "trivial" means "isomorphic to the terminal object" of whatever category it lies in?

There are some further subtleties involving basepoints and the empty space.

Alexander Campbell said:

There are some further subtleties involving basepoints and the empty space.

Let's see, so according to the definition as stated, XXX would be a (−1)(-1)(−1)-type if it is a 0-type and for every x∈Xx\in Xx∈X the pointed set π0(X,x)\pi_0(X,x)π0​(X,x) is isomorphic to 1. In other words, it is equivalent to a set, and if that set is inhabited then it is terminal. That seems to me a correct definition of a (−1)(-1)(−1)-type.

You're right that it doesn't work for n=−2n=-2n=−2, though; to get that definition right you can't have the "for all x∈Xx\in Xx∈X in there.

Thanks! Does somebody know whether the concept of the homotopy level of a Kan complex is discussed in Lurie's Kerodon or Higher Topos Theory? I couldn't find it under the names "homotopy level", "h-level", and "nnn-type".
It's definition 2.3.4.15 of the arxiv version of HTT, "kkk-truncated" (doesn't seem to be in Kerodon yet, a bit surprising)
also mentioned in the Terminology section before the table of contents

Alexander Campbell said:

Leopold Schlicht A Kan complex XXX "has homotopy level ≤n\leq n≤n”, or "is an nnn-type”, if for every k>n+1k > n+1k>n+1, every map of simplicial sets ∂Δk→X\partial\Delta^{k} \to X∂Δk→X extends to a map Δk→X\Delta^{k} \to XΔk→X, or equivalently, if for every m>nm > nm>n, and every base point x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, the homotopy group πm(X,x)\pi_m(X,x)πm​(X,x) is trivial.

I noticed that the first of these two equivalent conditions makes sense for each simplicial set (not only for Kan complexes). Does one sometimes use the attribute "has homotopy level ≤n\leq n≤n" for simplicial sets that that don't satisfy the Kan extension property? (If not, why not?)
I think it's a reasonable usage but it would no longer be equivalent to a lifting property. Instead, it would mean that a fibrant (Kan) replacement of the simplicial set has homotopy level ≤n\le n≤n.

Reid Barton said:

I think it's a reasonable usage but it would no longer be equivalent to a lifting property. Instead, it would mean that a fibrant (Kan) replacement of the simplicial set has homotopy level ≤n\le n≤n.

If one wants to define when an ∞\infty∞-category is an nnn-category, is this done in a similar way?

Can one consider the "homotopy category" construction from simplicial sets to 1-categories as a kind of "1-truncation"? How are the other truncations defined?
The first question is discussed in 2.3.4 in Higher Topos Theory, but the last question is still open (for me).
See Section 2 of the following paper of Raptis https://arxiv.org/pdf/1910.04117.pdf

Ah, nice, thanks! Now I recognize that Proposition 2.3.4.12 in Higher Topos Theory already discusses this construction, in particular it exhibits "the homotopy nnn-category of an ∞\infty∞-category" as a left adjoint to the inclusion of nnn-categories into ∞\infty∞-categories.

Alexander Campbell said:

Leopold Schlicht A Kan complex XXX "has homotopy level ≤n\leq n≤n”, or "is an nnn-type”, if for every k>n+1k > n+1k>n+1, every map of simplicial sets ∂Δk→X\partial\Delta^{k} \to X∂Δk→X extends to a map Δk→X\Delta^{k} \to XΔk→X, or equivalently, if for every m>nm > nm>n, and every base point x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, the homotopy group πm(X,x)\pi_m(X,x)πm​(X,x) is trivial.

Fix nnn. If XXX is any simplicial set with the property that for every k>n+1k>n+1k>n+1, every map of simplicial sets ∂Δk→X\partial \Delta^k\to X∂Δk→X extends to a map Δk→X\Delta^k\to XΔk→X, does it follow that XXX is a Kan complex? I know that in the case n=−2n=-2n=−2 the answer is yes: Kerodon/0076. (By definition, a contractible Kan complex is a simplicial set with the above property for n=−2n=-2n=−2.)
No. The nerve of any category has this property for n = 1.
Thanks! Is there any nnn except 111 for which this is true?
You mean, any nnn except −2-2−2?

It should be true for n=−1n=-1n=−1, since a simplicial set with that property is either empty or a contractible Kan complex. And I think it should be true for n=0n=0n=0, since a simplicial set with that property is a disjoint union of contractible Kan complexes. But once it fails for n=1n=1n=1 it's going to automatically fail for any n>1n>1n>1.
Ah, thanks!
